dt: {bc}of, relating to, or used in vision
{bc}of, relating to, or employing visual aids

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}visualis{/it}, from Latin {it}visus{/it} sight, from {it}vidēre{/it} to see
shortdef: of, relating to, or used in vision

dt: {bc}something (such as a graphic) that appeals to the sight and is used for effect or illustration

shortdef: something (such as a graphic) that appeals to the sight and is used for effect or illustration —usually used in plural

dt: {bc}the relative ability of the visual organ to resolve detail that is usually expressed as the reciprocal of the minimum angular separation in minutes of two lines just resolvable as separate and that forms in the average human eye an angle of one minute

shortdef: the relative ability of the visual organ to resolve detail that is usually expressed as the reciprocal of the minimum angular separation in minutes of two lines just resolvable as separate and that forms in the average human eye an angle of one minute

dt: {bc}an instructional device (such as a chart, map, or model) that appeals chiefly to vision

shortdef: an instructional device (such as a chart, map, or model) that appeals chiefly to vision; especially : an educational motion picture or filmstrip

dt: {bc}a sensory area of the occipital lobe of the cerebral cortex receiving afferent nerve fibers concerned with vision

shortdef: a sensory area of the occipital lobe of the cerebral cortex receiving afferent nerve fibers concerned with vision —called also visual area

dt: {bc}the entire expanse of space visible at a given instant without moving the eyes

shortdef: the entire expanse of space visible at a given instant without moving the eyes —called also field of vision

dt: {bc}the ability to recognize and understand ideas conveyed through visible actions or images (such as pictures)

shortdef: the ability to recognize and understand ideas conveyed through visible actions or images (such as pictures)

dt: {bc}a photosensitive red or purple pigment in the retinal rods of various vertebrates

shortdef: a photosensitive red or purple pigment in the retinal rods of various vertebrates; especially : rhodopsin

dt: {bc}a red photosensitive pigment in the retinal rods of the eye of most vertebrates that is important in vision in dim light

et: borrowed from German {it}Rhodopsin,{/it} from {it}rhod-{/it} {et_link|rhod-|rhodo-} + Greek {it}ópsis{/it} "appearance, sight, vision" + German {it}-in{/it} {et_link|-in:1|-in:1} {ma}{mat|optic:1|}{/ma}

Term introduced by the German physiologist Wilhelm Kühne (1837-1900) and his assistant August Ewald (1849-1924) in "Untersuchungen über den Sehpurpur," {it}Untersuchungen aus dem Physiologischen Institute der Universität Heidelberg,{/it} 1. Band (1878), p. 181: "Was den Sehpurpur im Dunkel ändert, pflegt es z. Th. in derselben Weise zu thun, wie das Licht, d.h. erst eine gelbe Materie, dann farblose Substanz hervorzubringen. Der Kürze wegen und um dem Auslande unsere Bezeichnungen zugänglich zu machen, kann man sagen, Rhodopsin werde erst in Xanthopsin, dieses in Leukopsin zersetzt." ("Those things [i.e., reagents] that convert visual purple in darkness in part act in the same manner as light, that is, they first produce a yellow material, then a colorless substance. For the sake of brevity, and in order to make our designations more accessible to foreigners, we can say that rhodopsin is first broken down into xanthopsin ['visual yellow'], and this into leucopsin ['visual white'].") Kühne's selection of the combining element {it}rhod-,{/it} usually meaning "red," is somewhat idiosyncratic, given that he is rendering German {it}Sehpurpur{/it} ("visual purple") and not {it}Sehrot{/it} ("visual red").
shortdef: a red photosensitive pigment in the retinal rods of the eye of most vertebrates that is important in vision in dim light —called also visual purple

dt: {bc}not {d_link|visible|visible:1} without the aid of special instruments {bc}{sx|subvisible||}

dt.t: … once you have seen the {wi}subvisual{/wi} world through the microscope, you stop inventing demons and magic as the agents of change.

Auroras have a wide range of brightness, usually rated from 0 to 4 on a logarithmic scale … in which each number is 10 times brighter than the previous one. Zero means {wi}subvisual{/wi}, detected only with instruments.

shortdef: not visible without the aid of special instruments : subvisible
